title: Overview
content: Archaeology is largely self-contained — all materials are gathered from excavation rather than traded, making it one of the more ironman-friendly skills in RS3. The training experience is essentially identical to regular play, with a few nuances around Chronotes and collection rewards.
The skill cap is level 120. Begin by completing the Archaeology Tutorial north of the Exam Center in Varrock, which takes you to level 5 and teaches the basics of excavation and artefact restoration.
Key concept: you excavate soil to uncover artefacts, restore them using materials you also excavate, then donate them to the Museum of the Archaeologists for Chronotes and XP rewards.

title: Getting Started (Levels 1–20): Kharid-et
content: After the tutorial, head to Kharid-et (east of Al Kharid, accessible from the Archaeology Guild) for your first dig site.
- Level 1–5: Tutorial excavation spots. You'll learn the basic mechanics here.
- Level 5–20: Kharid-et — Castra debris and other spots in the Praetorium area. Excavate Roman Legion artefacts and restore them for XP.
Materials needed at Kharid-et: leather scraps, animal furs, gold leaf, and terracotta. All gathered on-site.
- Tip: Restore artefacts in batches. You can stockpile damaged artefacts, then restore them all at the Archaeologist's bench.
- Complete the Kharid-et collection sets — donating full collections multiplies your Chronote reward.
Chronotes are the currency of Archaeology. Use them to buy materials, teleports, and other perks.

title: Levels 20–70: Everlight and Stormguard
content: At level 20, unlock the Everlight dig site (south-east of Draynor Village, past the Saradomin statue). This site has much higher XP rates than Kharid-et.
- Level 20–42: Everlight — Icyenic debris. Stained glass, marble, and silver are the main materials here.
- Level 42–70: Stormguard Citadel (accessed via a portal near Armadyl's tower, Feldip Hills region). Aviation debris and various Aviansie artefacts.
Stormguard is a major XP milestone. The site has excellent artefact density and the collections here give strong Chronote rewards.

- Tip: As you go higher in level, switch to higher-tier excavation spots within each site. At Stormguard, move from Aviation debris to Command centre debris (level 55) and War table debris (level 65).
Keep your materials stocked. If you run out, simply excavate more from the associated hotspot — materials always come from the same sites as the artefacts that need them.

title: Levels 70–99: Warforge and Orthen
content: Level 70 unlocks Warforge, the Bandosian dig site located in the Feldip Hills. It contains some of the densest artefact hotspots in the game.
- Level 70–83: Warforge — various spots including Goblin dye vats and Small goebie burial grounds.
- Level 83–99: Orthen (Anachronia). The Orthen site is home to Dragonkin artefacts and has the best XP per hour at this range.
At Orthen, focus on the Varanus cage (level 83) and Orthen furnace core spots as you level up.

- Unlocking mattocks: Better mattocks dramatically increase excavation speed. Craft or commission them as your level allows. The Elder Rune Mattock (level 80) and Ikovian Mattock (level 90) are key upgrades.
- Orthenglass: A special material from Orthen used to make the best mattocks and unlockable tools. Farm it as you dig here.

title: Levels 99–120: Senntisten and Endgame
content: Level 99 unlocks Senntisten (under Varrock, accessed through the Archaeology skill portal). This is the highest-level site and contains Zarosian artefacts.
- Level 99–107: Senntisten — various spots including Infernal Source overflow.
- Level 107–120: The highest-XP spots at Senntisten and continued Orthen rotations.
At this point, the XP rates are very high if you use optimal mattocks and research boosts.

- Research projects: Unlocked at the Archaeology Guild. Complete research to gain passive boosts (faster excavation, more soil per action, etc.). This is important throughout training but especially at high levels.
- Mysteries: Archaeology has a questline of mysteries — complete them for XP rewards, story, and access to powerful relics.

title: Ironman Tips
content: Archaeology has almost no ironman-specific restrictions — all materials are obtained through excavation and cannot be traded. This makes it a truly self-contained skill.
- Chronotes: Earned by donating artefact collections to the museum. Use them to buy Archaeology teleports (very convenient), mattock restoration, and research boosts.
- Cache of Ithell: Every 2 hours, a special cache spawns at an active dig site. Excavating it gives large XP bonuses — check your location and prioritise these.
- Museum of the Archaeologists: Donate full collections rather than individual artefacts. Full-set donations give significantly more Chronotes.
- Soil box: Unlocked early in the skill. Lets you store soil without dropping it, saving significant bank time.
- Tetracompass: Assembled from compass pieces found during excavation. Points to a special buried cache with high-value loot. Worth tracking as an ironman.
